thread.title: 'Watchmen' TV show; Billie Joe Armstrong's son making music; 'Empire' spinoff: PM Buzz
thread.title_full: 'Watchmen' TV show; Billie Joe Armstrong's son making music; 'Empire' spinoff: PM Buzz | syracuse.com

author: Geoff Herbert | gherbert@syracuse.com
title: 'Watchmen' TV show; Billie Joe Armstrong's son making music; 'Empire' spinoff: PM Buzz
text:
HBO is in talks for a "Watchmen" TV show , sources tell Collider . "Batman v Superman" director Zack Snyder, who helmed the 2009 movie based on Alan Moore's dark superhero comic books, is said to be discussing a series based on the characters Silk Spectre, Nite Owl, Ozymandias, Rorschach, Dr. Manhattan and the Comedian. It's unclear whether it'd be a prequel, sequel or a reboot, but word is the network wants a big budget hit for when "Game of Thrones" ends and something to help compete with the growing flood of superhero TV shows, including Netflix's "Daredevil," The CW's "Arrow," CBS' "Supergirl," Fox's "Gotham" and ABC's "Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D."
Green Day frontman Billie Joe Armstrong's son is making music that sounds a lot like, well, Green Day. Jakob Armstrong, 16, has signed with Burger Records (the same label that BJA's other son Joey, a drummer, is signed to with band Swmrs) under his solo moniker, Jakob Danger. He's released a handful of tracks that NME describes as angst-filled grunge punk rock, similar to Green Day (and Sweet Children) in the late '80s and early '90s.
TV's musical breakout hit "Empire" could get a spinoff series as early as next year, according to Fox TV Group co-CEO Dana Walden. "If there's a character... that feels original enough, has enough momentum and enough of a storytelling engine, we will definitely look to spin 'Empire' off for next season," she said. Creator Lee Daniels already said last month that another series based on the hip-hop drama would happen, possibly as a prequel about Taraji P. Henson's character Cookie Lyon.
» Read more at the Daily Mail .
And Syracuse University alumnus Aaron Sorkin thinks everyone's too mean these days. "I am dismayed at how entertained we have become at the expense of others. It doesn't speak well of us, and it's gotten much, much worse, obviously, with social media," the screenwriter complained while promoting his new "Steve Jobs" movie. "It feels to me like a lot of people talking and nobody listening. It's just a little quippy for me." Then Sorkin admits he's "got a lot of nerve" to call anything quippy.
» Read more at The New York Times .
